dataset_info.name: Medical Multimodal Multi-Lesion Dataset
dataset_info.description: Enhanced dataset supporting multiple lesions and multiple images with segmentation

patient_info.chief_complaint: Chronic cough and weight loss for 2 months

lesions.description: Spiculated nodule, 18mm diameter, concerning for malignancy
Small nodule, well-defined margins, likely benign
Small area of consolidation, possibly inflammatory

medical_record.history: Patient is a 68-year-old female with 40 pack-year smoking history. Progressive dyspnea and hemoptysis over past 2 months. 10 kg weight loss.
medical_record.physical_exam: Decreased breath sounds in right upper chest. No clubbing. Vital signs stable.
medical_record.lab_results: WBC 8.5, Hgb 11.2 (mild anemia), Tumor markers: CEA elevated at 12.3 ng/ml

reasoning_steps.observation: Multiple nodular opacities noted in both lungs, right predominant

reasoning_steps.action: Examine largest right upper lobe nodule
reasoning_steps.reference_text: Spiculation and size >15mm raises concern for primary lung cancer
reasoning_steps.reasoning: Irregular margins, spiculation, patient's smoking history and symptoms strongly suggest malignancy

reasoning_steps.action: Evaluate smaller right lower lobe nodule
reasoning_steps.reference_text: Size <10mm with smooth margins more consistent with benign etiology or satellite lesion
reasoning_steps.reasoning: Could be satellite metastasis given larger lesion, or benign granuloma

reasoning_steps.observation: Area of consolidation, air bronchograms present
reasoning_steps.reference_text: Air bronchograms suggest patent airways, more consistent with inflammatory process
reasoning_steps.reasoning: Likely post-obstructive pneumonia or concurrent infection

reasoning_steps.observation: Multiple findings: dominant spiculated mass, satellite nodule, and consolidation
reasoning_steps.reasoning: Combination of dominant malignant-appearing mass with satellite lesion and post-obstructive changes

intermediate_conclusions: Multiple pulmonary nodules identified, right predominant
Smaller lesions may represent satellite metastases
Left lower lobe consolidation likely post-obstructive

final_diagnosis.primary: Suspected lung cancer (T2N0M0, stage IB) with satellite lesions

lesions.description: Large heterogeneous mass with surrounding edema and mass effect

medical_record.history: Progressive headaches for 3 weeks, now with right-sided weakness and speech difficulty. No prior malignancy. No trauma.
medical_record.physical_exam: Alert but dysarthric. Right hemiparesis 4/5 strength. Positive Babinski on right. No papilledema.
medical_record.lab_results: Normal CBC and metabolic panel. No evidence of systemic infection.

reasoning_steps.observation: Large space-occupying lesion in right frontal lobe visible on all sequences
42mm heterogeneous mass with ring enhancement and central necrosis
reasoning_steps.reference_text: Ring enhancement with necrosis is classic for high-grade glioma or metastasis
reasoning_steps.reasoning: Imaging features consistent with glioblastoma multiforme

reasoning_steps.observation: Extensive FLAIR hyperintense signal surrounding mass
reasoning_steps.reasoning: Significant edema causing mass effect and midline shift, explains focal neurological deficits

reasoning_steps.observation: No other enhancing lesions identified in remaining brain parenchyma
reasoning_steps.reasoning: Single lesion favors primary brain tumor over metastatic disease

reasoning_steps.observation: Mass location explains right-sided weakness and speech difficulty
reasoning_steps.reasoning: Left frontal lobe involvement affecting motor cortex and Broca's area. Rapid progression over 3 weeks consistent with high-grade tumor
supporting_evidence: Focal neurological deficits matching lesion location

intermediate_conclusions: Large intra-axial mass in right frontal lobe
Imaging characteristics consistent with high-grade glioma

secondary: Significant perilesional edema with mass effect
